questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is a diagnosed case of depression. He is concerned about side effects of his medication and requests you to prescribe a drug least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bupropion

 

Among the given option, Bupropion has the least sexual side effects.

 

Bupropion

 

  • Atypical Antidepressant, NDRI (Norepinephrine Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Side effects – insomnia, restlessness, seizures
  • Minimal risk of sexual side effects, weight gain or sedation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escitalopram and Option D. Fluoxetine are SSRIs and they have long-term side effects including low libido, delayed orgasm, and poor erection.

 

Option B. Venlafaxine is a SNRI. It has side effects similar to SSRI and in addition, can cause anticholinergic side effects and hypertension.

questions.text: Identify the image and make the diagnosis (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichobezoar

 

The image shows a trichobezoar, which is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract, usually due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) associated with the psychiatric condition trichotillomania.

 

In trichotillomania, individuals have an irresistible urge to pull out their hair, and sometimes they may also swallow the hair. Over an extended period of time, the ingested hair can accumulate and form a solid mass called a trichobezoar. This hair ball can cause obstruction in the stomach or small intestine, leading to acute abdominal pain that requires surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Splenic rupture is incorrect as the image does not depict a ruptured spleen. A splenic rupture would typically present with intra-abdominal hemorrhage and signs of hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. Pancreatic necrosis is incorrect as the image does not show necrotic pancreatic tissue. Pancreatic necrosis is a severe complication of acute pancreatitis and would not present as a well-defined mass in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Polycystic kidney is incorrect as the image is not depicting the kidneys. Polycystic kidney disease is characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, causing enlargement and progressive loss of renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A trichobezoar is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) in patients with trichotillomania, and can cause acute abdominal pain due to obstruction.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with BMI 32, was on atypical antipsychotic drugs. She presented with a complaint of weight gain. Which of the following drugs is least commonly associated with weight gain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

Atypical antipsychotics are known to vary in their propensity to cause weight gain. Among the options given, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain.

 

Clozapine and olanzapine are the antipsychotics most commonly associated with significant weight gain, whereas ziprasidone and aripiprazole are associated with minimal to no weight gain.

 

Thus, in the case of a patient concerned about weight gain, ziprasidone would be the preferable choice.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: This drug is known to cause moderate weight gain in patients.

 

Option B. Quetiapine: This drug is also associated with weight gain, although not as much as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Option D. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic and is known to cause significant weight gain.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among antipsychotic medications, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain, making it a better option for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient was brought to the emergency department with confusion, ataxia, and bilateral lateral rectus palsy. The patient had been eating poorly for several weeks and had frequent episodes of vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wernicke's encephalopathy

 

This case presents the classic triad of Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Mental status changes (confusion)
  • Ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia (bilateral lateral rectus palsy) Plus risk factors:
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • Poor nutrition
  • Frequent vomiting These symptoms result from thiamine deficiency affecting specific brain regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delirium tremens: While also seen in alcoholics, DT presents 48-72 hours after last drink with agitation, autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, and visual hallucinations. The absence of these and presence of ophthalmoplegia makes it unlikely.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: This chronic condition presents with anterograde amnesia and confabulation, typically developing after untreated Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Alcohol induced psychosis: This presents primarily with hallucinations and delusions during or after heavy drinking, without the neurological signs seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognition of Wernicke's triad (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia) in alcoholic patients is crucial as immediate thiamine administration can prevent progression to irreversible Korsakoff psychosis.

questions.text: Which of the following medication used in ADHD acts primarily as an alpha-2A adrenergic receptor agonist? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Guanfacine

 

Guanfacine is a selective alpha-2A adrenergic receptor agonist that:

  • Improves prefrontal cortical cognitive function
  • Reduces sympathetic outflow from the CNS
  • Helps with impulse control and attention
  • Is particularly effective for ADHD symptoms with emotional dysregulation
  • Can be used as monotherapy or adjunct to stimulants

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reboxetine: This is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, but does not act as an alpha-2 agonist.

 

Option B. Atomoxetine: While effective in ADHD, atomoxetine works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), not as an alpha-2 agonist.

 

Option C. Methylphenidate: This is a stimulant medication that works by blocking dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake. It does not have direct alpha-2 agonist activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guanfacine's unique mechanism as an alpha-2A adrenergic receptor agonist makes it particularly useful in ADHD patients who cannot tolerate stimulants or need additional emotional regulation support.

questions.text: Patient with depression, which medicine is appropriate?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoxetine

 

Fluoxetine is an SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor) and is considered the first-line treatment for depression. SSRIs are preferred due to their efficacy and better side effect profile  compared to other classes of antidepressants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium: Lithium is primarily used in the treatment of bipolar disorder to manage both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication typically used for conditions like schizophrenia and delusional disorders.

 

Option D. Imipramine: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) and can be used to treat  depression. However, TCAs generally have more side effects and are less safe compared to SSRIs, making fluoxetine a more appropriate choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is the first-line treatment for depression due to its efficacy and favorable side effect profile.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: A couple presents to the sexology clinic with complaints of decreased sexual satisfaction. The husband reports anxiety during intimate moments, difficulty maintaining erections, and focusing excessively on performance rather than pleasure. The wife notes that this has led to avoidance of physical intimacy. Which non-pharmacological technique would be most appropriate? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensate Focus Technique

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical presentation indicates performance anxiety and erectile dysfunction with avoidance behavior. Sensate Focus Technique is the most appropriate choice because:

  • It involves progressive, non-demanding touching exercises
  • Removes pressure of sexual performance by initially focusing on non-genital pleasuring
  • Helps reduce anxiety by emphasizing sensation rather than performance
  • Gradually builds intimate communication and comfort between partners
  • Specifically designed for couples dealing with sexual anxiety and erectile issues

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relaxation exercises: While helpful for general anxiety, these are not specifically designed for sexual dysfunction and don't address the interpersonal aspects of the problem.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is primarily used for obsessive-compulsive disorder and anxiety disorders. It's not specifically tailored for sexual dysfunction.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy: While CBT can help address underlying anxiety, it's more general and doesn't provide the specific structured physical intimacy exercises needed in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of erectile dysfunction with performance anxiety:

  1. Sensate Focus Technique is the preferred non-pharmacological intervention
  2. The technique progressively builds physical intimacy without performance pressure
  3. It addresses both the physical and psychological aspects of sexual dysfunction
  4. Focus is on pleasure and sensation rather than performance
  5. Partner involvement is crucial for successful outcomes

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Eonism: a. Sexual gratification by cross-dressing. This term is used to describe individuals who derive sexual pleasure from dressing in clothes traditionally worn by the opposite gender.
  2. Frotteurism: b. The act of rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person, usually in a crowded place, such as public transport. It is considered a paraphilic disorder.
  3. Necrophilia: c. Sexual stimulation by corpses. This is a rare and extreme paraphilia where individuals are sexually aroused by deceased bodies.
  4. Algolagnia: d. Sexual gratification in inflicting or suffering pain. This can involve either sadism (inflicting pain) or masochism (receiving pain) as part of sexual activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having tapping movements and lack of attention. He seems to be irritated, disturbing others, and restless most of the time. What should be the drug to be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylphenidate

 

The boy's symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and restlessness are indicative of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is the first-line treatment for ADHD and is FDA-approved for use in children aged six years and older. It is a stimulant medication that has been found to be more effective in managing ADHD symptoms compared to non-stimulants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atomoxetine: A non-stimulant medication also used to treat ADHD but generally considered when stimulants are not effective or cause intolerable side effects.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Another non-stimulant medication for ADHD, typically used as an adjunctive treatment or when stimulants are not suitable.

 

Option D. Clozapine: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and not indicated for ADHD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for managing ADHD in children six years and older due to its effectiveness in reducing symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity.

questions.text: During TURP, the surgeon takes care to dissect above the verumontanum to prevent injury to: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External urethral sphincter

 

Explanation:

 

The verumontanum, also known as the seminal colliculus, is an important anatomical landmark during Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP). It is crucial for the surgeon to avoid dissecting below this landmark to prevent damage to the external urethral sphincter, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. Injury to this sphincter can lead to complications such as urinary incontinence.

 

Key Anatomical Landmark in TURP:

 

 

The verumontanum serves as a critical stopping point for resection during TURP to avoid the external urethral sphincter and reduce the risk of post-operative complications related to urinary continence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral crest: The urethral crest is located within the prostatic urethra but is not as critical in the context of avoiding injury during TURP.

 

Option C. Prostatic utricle: The prostatic utricle is a small indentation in the prostatic urethra, but its injury is less consequential than that of the external urethral sphincter.

 

Option D. Trigone of the bladder: The trigone of the bladder is located within the bladder itself and is not relevant to the TURP procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During TURP, dissection above the verumontanum is crucial to prevent injury to the external urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Alzheimer's disease?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

 

The Nucleus of Meynert (a group of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain) is indeed affected in AD, leading to a decrease in acetylcholine, which contributes to the memory deficits seen in this disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects the elderly. The key findings in AD are:

 

Option A. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are seen: True. These are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

 

Option B. Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found: True. These plaques are extracellular and are composed of beta-amyloid protein.

 

Option D. Short term memory is affected: True. This is one of the hallmark clinical features of AD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is characterized by both intracellular neurofibrillary tangles and extracellular neuritic plaques. Cholinergic deficits, especially from the degeneration of the Nucleus basalis of Meynert, play a significant role in the memory impairments observed in these patients.

questions.text: The persistence of ADHD in childhood increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Children with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence. ADHD is characterized by impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention, which can lead to difficulty in following rules, controlling behavior, and maintaining social norms. When these symptoms persist into adolescence, they can manifest as more serious behavioral problems, such as conduct disorder, characterized by aggressive, antisocial, or defiant behaviors.

 

Conduct disorder is a common progression from ADHD because the underlying impulsivity and lack of self-control associated with ADHD often worsen over time, particularly when untreated. This progression underscores the importance of early intervention in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Note - Children with ADHD are at risk of developing depression, antisocial personality disorder, substance use disorder, and conduct disorder as adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This disorder involves a consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in other situations, and it is more associated with anxiety disorders rather than ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: This condition involves recurrent episodes of eating large quantities of food, often quickly and to the point of discomfort. It is associated more with emotional regulation issues rather than impulsivity or behavioral problems typical of ADHD.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: This disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about separation from attachment figures. It is more commonly associated with anxiety disorders and does not have a direct link to ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The persistence of ADHD in childhood significantly increases the risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence, highlighting the need for early and effective management of ADHD symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

  

The patient’s symptoms of agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors are indicative of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs due to excessive serotonergic activity in the nervous system, usually as a result of combining medications that increase serotonin levels, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. In this case, the combination of sertraline (an SSRI), an MAO inhibitor, and amitriptyline (a TCA) significantly increases serotonin, leading to the development of serotonin syndrome.

 

Symptoms of Serotonin Syndrome: (Mnemonic – RASH D)

 

  • Restlessness
  • Agitation
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Diarrhea

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with serotonin receptor antagonist properties, making it the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome. It works by blocking serotonin receptors, thereby reducing the excessive serotonergic activity causing the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage agitation and seizures but does not directly treat the underlying cause of serotonin syndrome. It is used as supportive therapy but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is a supplement often used in metabolic conditions and does not play a role in treating serotonin syndrome. It has no effect on serotonin levels or receptor activity.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and other specific conditions. It has no role in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin syndrome can occur when serotonergic drugs are combined, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome is Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency and is found to have raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis. The mother reports that she saw her consuming a substance in an unknown dose. What is the likely substance? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

  

The patient presents with symptoms of sympathetic overactivity, including raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis (excessive sweating), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These symptoms are characteristic of stimulant intoxication, particularly with substances that increase the release of catecholamines, such as cocaine. Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that induces a surge of dopamine, leading to intense sympathetic activation, which matches the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that causes respiratory and cardiovascular depression, pinpoint pupils (miosis), and reduced sympathetic activity, which is the opposite of what is observed in this case.

 

Option C. Heroin: Like morphine, heroin is an opioid that results in symptoms of sedation, respiratory depression, and miosis, rather than the sympathetic overdrive seen here.

 

Option D. Chlordiazepoxide: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that acts as a sedative and anxiolytic. It would typically cause sedation, hypotension, and muscle relaxation, not the heightened sympathetic response observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication is associated with signs of sympathetic overactivity, including elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis.

questions.text: A teacher discusses the importance of hand hygiene in preventing disease transmission and shares stories of how proper handwashing saved lives during epidemics. The students develop a positive attitude towards handwashing and voluntarily promote it among their peers. What kind of learning is going on here? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Affective

 

This scenario demonstrates affective learning because:

  • Students develop values and attitudes about hand hygiene
  • They internalize the importance of the behavior
  • They show emotional engagement with the concept
  • They demonstrate willingness to promote the behavior
  • The learning impacts their feelings and beliefs about hygiene

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cognitive: While students gain knowledge about handwashing, the primary focus is on developing attitudes and values rather than just understanding facts.

 

Option B. Psychomotor: This would involve learning the physical skills of handwashing, which isn't the focus here. The scenario emphasizes attitude development rather than motor skills.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: While some cognitive learning occurs, the primary domain is affective as evidenced by the change in attitudes and values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affective learning involves changes in feelings, attitudes, and values. It's demonstrated when students develop positive attitudes towards health behaviors and willingly promote them to others.

questions.text: A concerned mother reports that her adolescent daughter has developed unusual eating behaviors over the past few months. The daughter consumes multiple burgers in a single sitting and has observed her vomiting after the meals on multiple occasions. The daughter's BMI is calculated at 27. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The clinical presentation of binge eating (consuming multiple burgers in a single sitting) followed by purging (vomiting after meals) in a person with a higher BMI is indicative of bulimia nervosa. Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as vomiting, use of laxatives, or excessive exercise to prevent weight gain. Patients with bulimia nervosa usually have a normal or above-average BMI, distinguishing it from anorexia nervosa, where patients are typically underweight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa: While anorexia nervosa can involve binge eating and purging, it is usually associated with a significantly lower BMI. The patient would typically be underweight, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Pica: Pica involves the consumption of non-food items, such as soil or chalk, and does not involve binge eating or purging behaviors.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder: This disorder involves recurrent episodes of binge eating without subsequent purging or other compensatory behaviors. The absence of purging behavior in binge eating disorder differentiates it from bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:


Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by purging, often seen in individuals with a normal or above-average BMI.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder where a child speaks in some settings (like home) but consistently remains silent in others (like school).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: Children with depression might withdraw but don't exhibit selective mutism.

 

Option B. Childhood psychosis: Psychosis presents with hallucinations or delusions, not selective mutism.

 

Option D. Hyperkinetic disorder: ADHD involves inattention or hyperactivity, not selective silence in specific scenarios.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent failure to speak in specific situations, despite being able to speak in others.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3719.

questions.text: Treatment of benzodiazepine overdose? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flumazenil

 

Flumazenil is the drug of choice for treating benzodiazepine overdose. It acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing the effects of benzodiazepines. By administering flumazenil, the respiratory depression and sedation caused by benzodiazepine overdose can be counteracted, making it a crucial antidote in such situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fomepizole is incorrect as it is used in the treatment of methanol toxicity, not benzodiazepine overdose. Fomepizole acts as an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, preventing the metabolism of methanol to its toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Naltrexone is incorrect as it is primarily used for the treatment of alcohol relapse and opioid dependence, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that helps reduce cravings and prevents the rewarding effects of alcohol and opioids.

 

Option D. Naloxone is incorrect as it is the drug of choice for opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, acting as a competitive antagonist at the GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

choices.text: Schism and Skew represent abnormal family patterns in Obsessive Compulsive disorders
Schism describes a dominant mother and a submissive father
Skew is more relevant in the context of male children

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skew is more relevant in the context of male children

 

Explanation:

 

Schism and Skew are two types of intra-familial environments described by Lidz in the context of families of schizophrenic patients. These family patterns are particularly associated with the development of schizophrenia rather than obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).

 

Schism:

 

Schism refers to a situation of marital conflict and hostility between parents, where neither parent consistently yields to the other. This creates a divided family environment where children are caught in the middle, often being used as pawns in the parents' conflicts. This type of family environment is more commonly associated with schizophrenia in females than in males.

 

Skew:

 

Skew, on the other hand, describes a family environment where there is a dominant (typically the mother) and a submissive parent (typically the father). The dominant parent exerts a strong influence over the family, while the submissive parent is more passive. This pattern of family dynamics is thought to provide a poor role model, especially for male children, and is considered particularly relevant to the development of schizophrenia in male children.

 

Key Differences Between Schism and Skew:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schism and Skew represent abnormal family patterns in obsessive compulsive disorders : Incorrect. Schism and Skew are associated with schizophrenia, not OCD.

 

Option B. Skew describes hostility between parents : Incorrect. Skew involves a dominant and a submissive parent, not hostility between them.

 

Option C. Schism describes a dominant mother and a submissive father : Incorrect. Schism refers to hostility and conflict between parents, not a dominant and submissive dynamic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schism and Skew are family patterns associated with schizophrenia, with Skew being particularly relevant to male children due to the influence of a dominant parent (typically the mother) and a submissive parent (typically the father).

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: Which of the following psychological coping strategies is not considered a defense mechanism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Replacement

 

Defense mechanisms are unconscious psychological strategies used by individuals to cope with reality and maintain self-image. Among the options provided, rationalization, displacement, and regression are well-known defense mechanisms.

 

However, Replacement is not considered a recognized psychological defense mechanism. The term "replacement" might refer to various coping strategies or processes, but it is not classified as a defense mechanism in psychological theory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rationalization: This is a defense mechanism where individuals create a seemingly logical reason for irrational or unacceptable behaviors or feelings to avoid the true explanation.

 

Option B. Displacement: This defense mechanism allows a person to transfer feelings or reactions from the original object or person to a safer substitute. For example, someone angry at their boss might instead take out their frustration on a family member.

 

Option C. Regression: This occurs when an individual faced with stress retreats to an earlier developmental stage. For instance, an adult under stress might start behaving like a child, engaging in activities or behaviors typical of a younger age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Replacement" is not classified as a defense mechanism, whereas rationalization, displacement, and regression are recognized defense mechanisms used to protect oneself from anxiety or unacceptable impulses.

questions.text: Seman's squeeze technique is used for which of the following conditions?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature ejaculation

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a behavioral therapy method used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the man or his partner squeezing the tip of the penis for several seconds right before ejaculation is expected. This helps in delaying ejaculation. The other options do not involve the use of this technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation refers to the backward flow of semen into the bladder instead of out of the penis.

 

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection suitable for intercourse. 

 

Most successful psychotherapy for erectile dysfunction is dual-sex therapy by Masters and Johnson.

 

Option D. Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation is pain felt during or after ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as stop-start technique. Another non-pharmacological treatment includes squeeze technique, where the female partner squeezes the coronal ridge of the glans, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, a patient began to express strong feelings of anger towards her therapist, similar to those she had towards her father in childhood. This phenomenon is known as? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transference

 

Transference occurs when a patient unconsciously redirects feelings, attitudes, and expectations from past relationships (particularly early childhood) onto the therapist. Key features include:

  • Unconscious process
  • Based on past relationships/experiences
  • Can involve positive or negative emotions
  • Common in psychodynamic therapy
  • Important therapeutic tool when recognized and addressed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Countertransference: This refers to the therapist's emotional reactions towards the patient, not the patient's feelings towards the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: This is a defense mechanism involving disconnection from thoughts, feelings, or identity. It doesn't describe the transfer of feelings from past relationships.

 

Option D. Projection: While related to transference, projection specifically involves attributing one's own unacceptable thoughts or feelings to others, rather than redirecting past relationship patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding transference is crucial in psychotherapy as it provides insight into the patient's past relationships and emotional patterns, making it a valuable tool for therapeutic intervention.

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute and fluctuating onset with disturbances in consciousness and attention. Dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, has a gradual, insidious onset and is primarily a disorder of memory without loss of consciousness.

 

Delirium and dementia, though distinct syndromes, can sometimes overlap in presentation, making differentiation challenging. However, some key features can help differentiate the two:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acuity of onset and agitation: While the acuity of onset can differentiate the two, both delirium and dementia can be associated with agitation.

 

Option C. Visual hallucinations and impaired memory: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium and some types of dementia like Lewy Body Dementia but not necessarily Alzheimer's disease. Impaired memory is a feature of dementia, primarily Alzheimer's, but can also be present in delirium.

 

Option D. Agitation and irritation: Both can be seen in either delirium or dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: A patient develops acute confusion and disorientation shortly after undergoing surgical intervention for a malignant tumor. Which of the following medications is typically the first-line treatment for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haloperidol

 

The patient is experiencing acute confusion and disorientation following surgery, which suggests the development of delirium. Delirium is a common postoperative complication, especially in older adults or those with significant medical conditions. The first-line treatment for delirium, particularly when it is accompanied by psychotic symptoms or severe agitation, is antipsychotic medication. Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic that is commonly used in this situation due to its efficacy in controlling these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for delirium. It is more appropriate in the treatment of delirium tremens, which is a specific type of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal. In cases of delirium not related to alcohol withdrawal, lorazepam can actually worsen the confusion.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another antipsychotic that can be used to treat delirium, but it is not considered the first-line treatment as Haloperidol is more commonly preferred in acute cases.

 

Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone is also an antipsychotic that can be used in the management of delirium, but similar to Olanzapine, Haloperidol is generally preferred as the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haloperidol is the first-line treatment for delirium, especially when the patient exhibits significant agitation or psychotic symptoms following surgery.

questions.text: A patient developed sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine. He is suffering from a psychiatric illness and is on medications for the same. Which is the drug he is likely to be using? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MAOIs

 

The patient in the question is likely taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) for his psychiatric illness.

 

MAOIs are known to cause a "Cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas. Normally, tyramine is broken down by monoamine oxidase enzymes in the body. However, when a person is taking MAOIs, these enzymes are inhibited, leading to an accumulation of tyramine. The excess tyramine can cause a sudden and dangerous increase in blood pressure, resulting in a hypertensive episode.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SSRIs work by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option C. SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SNRIs work by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option D. TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants): Incorrect. While TCAs can have some effects on blood pressure, they do not inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes and do not lead to the accumulation of tyramine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) can cause a "cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas due to the inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes and the accumulation of tyramine.

choices.text: They are perceived in the objective space
They are not under the control of the patient

questions.text: All  are features of pseudohallucinations, except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They are perceived in the objective space

 

Explanation:

 

True Hallucinations are characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Perception happens without any real object or stimulus triggering it.
  2. They are as vivid and detailed, similar to real perceptions. For example, if a person is experiencing a visual hallucination, the image they see can appear very clear and detailed to them, almost indistinguishable from reality.
  3. Hallucination are perceived in the outer and objective space (external environment).
  4. They are not under the control of the patient. This means the patient cannot start or stop these perceptions at will; they occur spontaneously.

 

Importantly, Pseudohallucinations are perceived in the inner and subjective space, not the outer and objective space. These are perceived as coming from the inner from his/her mind.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They occur without stimulus: This is correct for pseudohallucinations as they happen without any external trigger.

 

Option C. They are vivid: This is also correct for pseudohallucinations. Despite not being real, the perceptions can be very detailed and clear.

 

Option D. They are not under the control of the patient: This is another correct feature of pseudohallucinations. Patients cannot control when these perceptions occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudohallucinations are vivid perceptions without stimulus, occurring in the inner and subjective space, and are not under the control of the patient.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented for evaluation. During the session, he was quite charming, and there is a history of him behaving nicely with family members. However, he often gets in fights with friends. He was also involved in multiple police cases. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antisocial personality

 

The description provided in the question fits the criteria for Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). Key characteristics of ASPD include a disregard for others' rights, frequent conflicts with social norms, legal issues, and manipulative or deceitful behavior. This individual displays charm during sessions, which is common among people with antisocial personality, as they can be superficially charming and convincing. The fact that he is often involved in fights and has multiple police cases further supports the diagnosis of ASPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Narcissistic personality: Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by grandiosity, a constant need for admiration, and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often talk about themselves, praise themselves excessively, and have a sense of entitlement. This patient's behavior does not include any such characteristics; instead, it focuses on antisocial behaviors.

 

Option C. Schizotypal personality: Schizotypal Personality Disorder is marked by eccentric behavior, discomfort with close relationships, and cognitive or perceptual distortions. There is no evidence in the question indicating any such traits, such as odd beliefs, social anxiety, or unusual thinking.

 

Option D. Paranoid personality: Paranoid Personality Disorder involves a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others. People with this disorder frequently believe others are out to harm or deceive them. This patient shows no signs of suspiciousness or paranoia; his behavior is more aligned with antisocial conduct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of disregard for others' rights, often involving legal issues, deceitful behavior, and superficial charm.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a Delusional Misidentification Syndrome? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capgras Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Capgras Syndrome is a type of delusional misidentification syndrome where the patient holds a delusional belief that someone close to them, usually a family member or spouse, has been replaced by an imposter who looks identical. This syndrome is often associated with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ekbom’s Syndrome: Also known as delusional parasitosis, where the patient falsely believes their body is infested with parasites.

 

Option C. Cotard’s Syndrome: A nihilistic delusion where the patient believes that they are dead or that parts of their body do not exist.

 

Option D. Othello Syndrome: Characterized by delusional jealousy, where the patient believes their partner is unfaithful without any real evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras Syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome involving the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an identical imposter.

questions.text: Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in which type of dementia? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dementia with lewy body

 

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by a similar-looking stranger.

 

While Capgras syndrome is usually seen in Schizophrenia, it can also occur in patients with dementia. Among the various types of dementia, Capgras syndrome is most commonly associated with Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), followed by Alzheimer's disease. In a patient with Capgras syndrome and dementia, the patient may believe that their spouse or a family member has been replaced by an identical impostor, leading to conflicts and distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease is the second most common type of dementia associated with Capgras syndrome, after dementia with Lewy bodies.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia is not typically associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Option D. Frontotemporal dementia is not commonly associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras syndrome, a delusion of misidentification where a patient believes a familiar person has been replaced by an identical impostor, is most commonly seen in dementia with Lewy bodies, followed by Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male needs to be dressed in female lingerie and high heels to feel aroused and have intercourse with a female; he denies any sexual attraction towards males. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic fetishism

 

Transvestic fetishism involves the act of cross-dressing to achieve sexual arousal. In this case, the individual derives sexual excitement from wearing female clothing while engaging in sexual activity with females, which is characteristic of transvestic fetishism. He denies any attraction toward males, which further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender dysphoria involves a strong discomfort or distress with one’s assigned gender and a desire to be the opposite gender. There is no evidence in this scenario of dissatisfaction with his gender identity or discomfort with his sexual organs, ruling out gender dysphoria.

 

Option C. Homosexual orientation: Homosexual orientation refers to sexual attraction toward members of the same sex. The individual in this scenario specifically denies any sexual attraction to males, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

 

Option D. Testicular feminization: Testicular feminization, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome, is a genetic condition where an individual has a male karyotype (XY) but develops as a female due to insensitivity to androgens. This condition is unrelated to sexual arousal patterns or behaviors, and there is no evidence to support this diagnosis in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic fetishism is characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in individuals who do not have discomfort with their gender identity.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive thoughts that, he always feels his hands are dirty, though they are not. This gives him discomfort and hence he has to wash them again and again. This is a disorder of thought:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Possession

 

The patient is experiencing obsessive thoughts. Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts that cause significant anxiety or distress. The individual recognizes that the obsessions are a product of his or her own mind, but they feel as though they can't control the thoughts, hence they fall under the category of disorders of thought possession.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Flow: Refers to the rate and speed of thoughts. Examples of disorders of flow include flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking.

 

Option B. Form: Refers to the organization and structure of thought. Examples of disorders of form include tangentiality, circumstantiality, and word salad.

 

Option D. Content: Refers to what person is actually thinking about, such as delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obsessions, as seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder, are considered disturbances of thought possession because while the individual recognizes the thoughts as their own, they feel as though they can't control them.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 46.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an OCD related disorder?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temper tantrums

 

Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders include conditions that share features with OCD, such as repetitive behaviors or obsessive thoughts.

 

Temper tantrums, on the other hand, are emotional outbursts seen typically in children and are not directly related to OCD or its spectrum disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania): Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania) is characterized by repetitive hair pulling resulting in hair loss.

 

Option C. Hoarding disorder: Hoarding disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty discarding possessions, leading to clutter.

 

Option D. Skin picking (Excoriation disorder): Skin picking (Excoriation disorder) involves recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 418-436.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is more common in Anorexia Nervosa when compared to Bulimia Nervosa? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Amenorrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Amenorrhea is more frequently associated with anorexia nervosa, primarily due to the effects of significant caloric restriction and weight loss on the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Starvation leads to a drop in GnRH, which lowers FSH and LH levels, resulting in decreased estrogen and subsequent menstrual irregularities or absence. While amenorrhea was once a diagnostic criterion in DSM-IV and ICD-10, it is no longer required in DSM-5 or ICD-11—but it remains a common clinical feature.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Dental Caries: More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia.
  • Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism.
  • Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.

 

Educational Objective:


Amenorrhea is a hallmark physiological consequence of the nutritional and hormonal imbalances seen in anorexia nervosa. Recognizing this and other subtle distinctions between anorexia and bulimia can help guide both diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

The patient described in the question is suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). BDD is a mental health condition characterized by an excessive preoccupation with an imagined defect in appearance, or if a minor physical anomaly is present, the person's concern is markedly excessive. Patients often have poor or absent insight, believing firmly in the existence of their perceived defects.

 

The standard treatment for BDD includes Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) (DOC) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Even when a patient's insight is at a delusional level, SSRIs remain the first-line pharmacological treatment, as they help reduce obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors associated with the disorder. In this case, SSRIs would be the best management option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Behavioural therapy: While behavioral therapy might offer some benefits, the specific first-line treatment for BDD is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), which targets the distorted beliefs about appearance directly. The term "Behavioral Therapy" is broad and less specific, making SSRIs a more targeted choice.

 

Option C. Atypical antipsychotics: These medications are not considered first-line treatment for BDD. They may be used as adjuncts in severe cases where delusional beliefs persist despite SSRIs, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Allow her for surgery: Surgery is not a recommended treatment for BDD as it does not address the underlying psychiatric condition and often worsens the patient's mental health state by reinforcing their preoccupation with appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and breathlessness but was medically fit. The patient is refusing to go back home and he doesn’t want to leave the hospital. The patient gives a history of robbery under gun-point that happened 10 days ago. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute stress disorder

 

The patient experienced a traumatic event 10 days ago and is now presenting with anxiety symptoms, making acute stress disorder the most probable diagnosis.

 

Acute stress disorder is characterized by the development of severe anxiety and other symptoms within one month after exposure to an extreme traumatic stressor. These symptoms include intrusive thoughts, flashbacks, and avoidance behavior, although the given case focuses on anxiety.

 

The duration of symptoms is crucial: if symptoms persist for more than one month, the diagnosis shifts to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoidant personality disorder: This cannot be diagnosed based on a single event; it requires a lifelong pattern of behavior characterized by social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation.

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: This involves persistent delusions without other major psychotic symptoms. There is no mention of delusions in the patient's history.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia: This diagnosis requires symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and other psychotic behaviors persisting for at least six months. The patient's history does not suggest these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute stress disorder occurs within one month of a traumatic event and is characterized by anxiety and other stress-related symptoms. If symptoms last longer than one month, the diagnosis changes to PTSD.

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

The patient's presentation of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, along with a history of chronic alcohol use, is indicative of a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This clinical picture is consistent with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Alcohol use can lead to poor dietary intake and absorption, contributing to thiamine deficiency. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of mental confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency in Vitamin B2 can lead to symptoms like skin disorders, anemia, and sore throat, but it is not typically associated with the neurological symptoms described in this scenario.
